Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the removal officer properly exercise discretion in refusing to defer removal? Were the daughter's s. 7 Charter rights engaged?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, section 48
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed her visa, had an unsuccessful humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) application, and requested deferral due to her daughter’s medical needs. Medical care availability in St. Vincent was confirmed by the officer.
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Deferral of removal on humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Failed to leave Canada after visa expiration
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations based on child’s medical condition
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Limited discretion of removal officers under IRPA s. 48; threshold for s. 7 Charter engagement
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Availability of medical care in country of origin, financial concerns unsubstantiated
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Medical reports, H&C application records, confirmation of healthcare access in St. Vincent
Crimes.Application_Basis: Request for deferral of removal based on family circumstances
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Medical documentation, prior H&C decision, country conditions
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Removal officers not required to conduct full H&C assessment; s. 7 applies only if state action directly threatens life, liberty, or security
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence that daughter would lack necessary care in St. Vincent
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: No direct harm from state action established
Crimes.Cause_Description: Applicant overstayed her visa and sought deferral of removal due to her daughter’s medical condition
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Officer reviewed existing medical and immigration records
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: No new evidence presented post-H&C refusal
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of removal officer under federal immigration law
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer assessed medical and logistical factors; found no barrier to removal
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer acted reasonably within mandate; no obligation to reconsider H&C factors; daughter's s. 7 rights not engaged
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Insufficient evidence to demonstrate risk upon return
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard applied to administrative decision; Charter s. 7 threshold not met

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Violation_Type: Immigration violation - non-compliance with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the removal officer properly exercise discretion in refusing to defer removal? Were the child's section 7 Charter rights engaged?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, section 48
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada after visa expiry, subject to removal order. Daughter is Canadian citizen with medical needs. Officer confirmed adequate care available in St. Vincent. No new evidence after H&C refusal.
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Deferral of removal on humanitarian and family grounds
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Continued illegal stay despite removal order
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Humanitarian concerns related to dependent child’s health
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Limited discretion under IRPA s. 48; s. 7 Charter requires direct state deprivation affecting life, liberty, or security
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Availability of medical treatment in home country, citizenship status of child, absence of new evidence
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of removal deferral decision
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Medical records, H&C application outcome, country condition information
Crimes.Application_Basis: Request to defer removal based on child’s medical condition
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Prior H&C assessment, medical reports, feasibility of care in St. Vincent
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Removal officers focus on practicality of removal; no duty to re-evaluate H&C unless new evidence
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No new or compelling evidence demonstrating inability to access care abroad
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: No direct threat to child’s well-being by state action established
Crimes.Cause_Description: Applicant's visitor visa expired, leading to illegal stay and eventual removal order despite humanitarian concerns
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Existing evidence reviewed; no additional submissions altered assessment
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA s. 48(1), failure to comply with removal direction
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: Lack of updated or persuasive evidence post-H&C refusal
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – failed to depart after removal order
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of authority of removal officer under federal immigration framework
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Assessed as insufficient to justify deferral
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer acted reasonably; no new factors warranted intervention; child’s s. 7 rights not engaged
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to provide new or compelling evidence supporting deferral
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard; Charter s. 7 not triggered without direct state interference
